title: Domain (ring theory)
summary: In algebra, a domain is a nonzero ring in which ab = 0 implies a = 0 or b = 0.[1] (Sometimes such a ring is said to "have the zero-product property".) Equivalently, a domain is a ring in which 0 is the only left zero divisor (or equivalently, the only right zero divisor).   A commutative domain is called an integral domain.[1][2]  Mathematical literature contains multiple variants of the definition of "domain".[3]
